text: thank you very much andy dennis and yuri for inviting me it's a pleasure to be here when i first
accepted the invitation uh it was back in october and um we were
working on ebola that time and that probably got yuri's interest bugged up and luckily for all of us
although it continues to be a a problem i think things are looking much better so my
talk uh is going to be about computational epidemiology uh the role of big data and pervasive
informatics and before i go into the details i want to acknowledge my collaborators
it's certainly not something that i've done alone this is a piece of work that spans over 20 years
and a number of folks in our lab as well as folks in other universities
and also the different funding agencies so i want to thank them for their support
so i have decided that given the diversity of the audience i
will try and keep the talk at a scientific american level um i'm happy to take questions
during the talk if that's easy and we can certainly discuss it at the end of the talk and what i thought was that i'll try and
have two basic goals for today's lecture one is to give you an overview of computational
epidemiology as a as a branch in in science with an emphasis
on computing and data science and how it helps helps this area i decided to do this because i
think in the systems lab this might be a topic that not everybody is is well versed with and the
second thing that i would like to illustrate through this talk is is this broad topic of computation for
social good i think this is a beautiful topical area for us as computer scientists to contribute to the
to the larger societal good and hopefully at the end of the talk some of you might feel interested and
and decide to work on this topic and if i've done that that would be a uh that would be a success for this talk
i've also tried to have maybe a little bit more in terms of words on the slides and
uh i did it just so that uh these slides are if read by others at the later time are
as much as possible self-contained uh so but i'll go through it slowly
luckily then we have a time till 5 30 which i was not aware of so i think we get enough time to discuss it
so let me start first with uh just defining some basic terms what is epidemics epidemics is really a
situation where the num incidents the number of folks who are falling sick or the
incidences that you're measuring in a community or region is substantially higher
than what is typically observed right so then that the the definition itself is a relative term
so for instance ebola is now viewed as an epidemic because the number of cases up until now are
very very small compared to what we have seen so far the term epidemiology comes from uh from
you know greek words epi and and demos and uh basically deals with
the study uh of the distribution determinants of health related states
and tries to find ways to control the health problems that people face
the basic term has been applied in the context of non-communicable diseases as well over time
and also to things like malware propagation in the internet so three three things are important in this
particular setting one is that you're talking about distributions you're not talking about
individual health as much as understanding population health and that's a distinction between epidemiology and medicine so to say
the second is your interest in causes for why this is happening so the determinants and finally you're
interested in application coming up with ways to control epidemics computational epidemiology or
mathematical epidemiology they're close related is a topic where you try and use mathematical sciences and computational
sciences to try and help epidemiologists address their scientific field so that's that's what
you know computational epidemiology in short is and i'll i'll discuss these aspects in detail so epidemics are
not new to us um you know it's at least as as old as as uh as the you know
history of of uh humankind in many ways uh and there is a set of good literature
articles that have been cited and i have some citations at the very end that you can take a read at but the good news is that
pandemics which is basically epidemics at a global proportion that happened have happened quite
periodically in history at least for the time being seem unlikely you know so the large
last big pandemic that happened was 1918 flew we had other pandemics after that but that
probably was the biggest in the last century by far probably affected almost every country
every every region in the world and we think that at least in the for
the time being such as such an event is unlikely to occur but most people would agree that we will
see a pandemic the question is when and the thing is that
even though we have made great strides in terms of finding out where the disease is
starting coming up with pharmaceutical interventions there are many new complicating factors
that i believe uh make the problem of addressing or solving this
you know controlling epidemics is uh is a challenging one so what what are the basic issues one is
that we are starting to live in cities that are larger and larger so the second thing is that cities are
getting more and more tightly packed the density in urban regions is growing
we also have immuno-compromised individuals many more folks who are older and folks who
who who have you know other other other diseases or health health problems which basically
makes them immunocompromise and increase the likelihood likelihood of them catching a
new disease and finally we we have over time as we've started growing in terms of
population we're really coming up to a situation at a place where we're starting to interact more
and more with the environment in nature we're sort of affecting it in a larger large way and i think ebola is an example where this
this might be playing out uh in in some ways where the boundaries of the cities is actually growing and we are we are
touching the habitat uh of of uh you know
of other other other animals and species in a manner that we have not done before in in in such large numbers
so we want to keep that in mind and so the the tools that we're going to try and develop hopefully we'll try and address these
issues i want to take an example from ebola the work that we have been working on and i'll tell you a little
bit more about it uh this has been the largest
ebola outbreak in the history uh ebola's history as we know started around 1970s uh sometime during
that time but this one has affected a much larger region three
three countries in in west africa with sporadic cases in nigeria that sort of went there mali
recently but uh it used to be that central africa was where ebola outbreaks happened but
this one moved into western africa and and affected now at least 20 000
individuals these are detected cases the general belief is that the number of cases is far more than 20 000
and has so far caused 8 000 odd deaths uh so this has got a huge uh you know
uh burden of disease uh in in terms of uh you know how many deaths it has caused and how many forces it has infected
moreover the countries are actually just overcoming a lot you know long social
uh problem in terms of civil war that was going on in these places so you know not only do we have this big
outbreak it's in countries which are relatively poor uh and just recovering from from
earlier political and and social problems and civil problems that they had and uh actually there's a very nice uh
you know uh web page that new york times has prepared and i have i look at it very very often folks here might want to look
at it which actually outlines uh you know many many issues that folks
who are epidemiologists or even you know a citizen scientist would be interested in reading
and the basic question that we want to study things like you know how many people have been infected where
is the outbreak where did it start how do you stop it these are all questions that we all as epidemiologists
are you know even citizen scientists and policy makers are interested in addressing and i think this website actually does a
very good job of cataloging these questions our goal here is to study what we call
real-time epidemic science and this is becoming more and more feasible over time and the basic idea is
that you you don't want to develop tools that are only useful during the planning
phase you know say for instance preparing tools right now for a future pandemic that might happen but really
work with the policy makers and and civil authorities and supporting them
as the disease is breaking out in real time now this is actually a non-trivial problem uh i think as a
society we become better at it but i think remains a really big open question uh in terms of
how we bring about uh uh you know changes and and build tools and and get policy
makers to agree on on problems of of the scale and size uh and actually a very nice article in
science some time back it was an editorial article by feinberg and and her his colleague about this question and they have
challenged the society to try and study and build tools to study you know develop tools for
epidemics you know control in in real time so
here are some questions that we have uh uh you know studied over over a number of years before but in the
context of ebola we've been studying them very actively and to just give you some sense uh
we started working on ebola uh approximately in uh in june july time frame uh working very
closely with uh you know several federal agencies and uh it has been an experience of of a
kind for us as a lab uh we're an academic institution but given what was happening on the ground
uh the work has been very intense and in some ways uh to us to uh
you know for us as modelers it's rewarding to see whether to try and support policy makers and i i
think at the end of the day the folks on the ground deserve a lot of credit you know the models we make is is one thing but
the folks who are really on the ground in these countries working out really deserve all the kudos from us and
support from us so this this is actually really small work in in terms of what these folks are doing is very
challenging questions so we started supporting some of the agencies in u.s
through interagency you know coordination meetings and initially the goal was simply to understand the epidemic
disease parameters you know the the rate at which the infection is getting you know trans you know the incubation
time of the disease uh how the disease is getting you know transmitted where it might be we started in
forecasting the disease and every week we actually give presentations where these forecasts are
provided to the policy makers and as my colleague has said
we are actually happy to to be proven wrong in our forecast our initial forecast actually said the numbers are going to
be much higher than what the current numbers report and i i personally think of this as actually
very good news and partly it's it's very hard to figure out whether our forecasts are wrong
or whether the forecast that our group and many other groups did really galvanize this
community to change certain habits that might have cut down on the disease
progression and this is something andy said in his in introduction where people are very
important elements of this unlike physical system where you can really deterministically say
where the moon is going to be you know in terms of its its position uh people adapt when they perceive diseases
and that's fundamentally a problem in social systems and and things like epidemics so we did
forecasting site forecasting problems we then studied um in september time frame
questions related to assessing the the chance of the disease coming to u.s you might have heard of the news on the
tv that time and and news outlets about uh you know cases that came to us
and luckily things things worked out and it was it was very clear as modelers that
unless we did something really stupid this is not going to you know spread in a way that has spread
in in liberia at that time we have far far well coordinated
system in in place we then studied uh efficiently allocating pharmaceuticals
now there's no vaccine for ebola right now but they're in the process there are some trials ongoing right now we expect
vaccines to come out sometime this year initially the thought was that will be very soon but i think it has been
delayed some we do expect vaccines to come out the current number you know trials which are very limited
suggest that they might be efficacious so we studied how vaccines could be allocated
uh how many would might be required uh you know where should they be provided
and questions of that sort another question we studied uh when we were working with the
agencies was to allocate uh you know resources in a very particular
setting which is a which is actually a operations research question which is to do with placing emergency treatment
units so as you know us decided to place between 10 and 20 emergency treatment units
uh the size and their scope was not clear early on and we did a study to to to at least
provide guidance in what what sort of treatment units would be most useful where would they be
placed what sort of benefits you would get uh some of the results were then taken in
and the questions are actually non-trivial right for instance you might actually intuitively feel like
placing a treatment unit where the disease burden is very high at this moment
but by the time the treatment unit gets in place uh the disease might have moved on to some other place so
it's not obvious where to place these units now if you might you might place it in a remote place where there's no
disease uh breakout at that point of time uh from a social standpoint it is not a
policy that goes very well to see something that is sitting there with nobody using it so it's actually an
interesting operations research question there will be now discussions about placing these units
in a manner they call you know treatment units in the box so they want to build smaller units potentially
that can be moved as they see the disease moving through the place now this is not a straightforward matter because you know
dismantle get the place working is a non-trivial issue but something to be considered
we've been studying uh you know need for protective gear you know face masks gloves and
other things we've also studied the use of twitter in assessing the public moods and sentiments we had done another project
before for flu which is very successful in using twitter data in in the us and latin american
countries but we found out that you know twitter is not used in in these countries
at a level that we would have uh you know wanted and as a result the
signal is rather weak uh to to make to use twitter that effectively at least at this point of
time and finally we we have studied the potential spread of ebola into latin american countries because
one of the conjectures or the thought was that you know
ebola would spread into latin american countries and through migrations and people moving into us you might
actually get a different route of of this disease coming into us so we wanted to study what the chances of such
a event happening were so you can see that these these questions are are very diverse requires a diverse team uh
we have over 70 folks in our lab and the questions really are posed almost
every week on a tuesday after our meeting is done and they want answers reasonably quickly
and as a as a as an academician this is actually an interesting exercise where you try and come up with some
solution that is meaningful and then you hopefully can refine it but you can't you can't say you gotta
wait for three months before i come up with an answer because that's simply not something that that works out in a situation like this and i think
that has been a very good learning experience for us as a lab to be working on a problem as an event
unfolds and i think more and more use of such tools uh will demand from policy makers uh that you know we
sort of try and support them in real time we've set up a web page um you know the
the address is uh is there on my slides and i think the slides are going to be posted andy as i understand
this webpage was built out as a resource uh for for ebola folks it has got a lot
of different pieces of information on it we build out you know data disease models and and
synthetic data for different countries papers have been put there and we continue to post new
new results and and analysis that comes out for instance all the presentations we have done
to our federal partners uh have been put on these slides uh with a few little bit of delay
uh just to make sure that the slides slides are okay and i encourage you folks to take a look at it
another thing that is of interest and i told this to yuri when i talked to him in october we
ran hackathon we call it hack ebola in in around october it probably was the first
ebola hackathon it was motivated by our students wanting to contribute to
this project and it was fairly successful we had 60 odd students participating in it
it was actually open to everybody outside got some projects done we also face some
challenges and challenges in terms of getting the right teams to work together was not straightforward one of our
students kaitlyn rivers was actually a key contributor in fact she was the one who coordinated this so and i
i think an exercise like this where students from various backgrounds come together to solve a
problem uh of of importance which i think is is interesting and i think uh something that we probably will do
again in spring because i think this problem is not going to go away anytime soon and i encourage students here
and other places to participate when this happens and after our hackathon there are multiple agencies
and universities that have also done it with varying degrees of success
again as i said depends on the problems you pose the the diversity of the teams that is
in place and sometimes the problems are not solvable in a day or two you know you require solutions which
take a little bit of time so this is a challenge that folks face so let me move to now the meat of the
talk and try to describe to you uh the mathematics behind it and at least give
you some sense so traditionally uh mathematical epidemiology worked with a
class of models called mass action compartmental models and the term mass action means that
you assume an interaction between populations and
individuals really are assumed to be identical in some form and compartmental in this case says that
there are three basic compartments the basic models really were motivated from chemical reactions and
people studying uh you know physical systems and a very early
version of it not called this way was used by daniel bernoulli when he talked about
videolation uh for controlling smallpox in france you know he basically is trying to argue that
um in you know variation which is the act of taking active smallpox from a
person who is infected and essentially in in vaccinating somebody
is actually a good thing because although there is a chance that somebody is going to fall sick and
fairly severely it protects provides herd immunity to the larger population and he did calculations which resemble
this and there's a very nice article by sally blauer uh on this topic that folks here might
be interested in reading so the simplest model has three compartments and this is the most elementary model this was
formalized in in early 1900s by ross and then mckendree kermick and
mckendrick and then by others where in this particular setting you
have compartments which denote susceptible individuals infected individuals and recovered
individuals and think of them as really chemical reactions or molecules uh if
for this purposes and then you talk about uh you know interactions between these compartments so you say the rate of
change of folks who are moving out of the susceptible compartment you know the
mass essentially to the infected is directly proportional to the
to sorry
directly proportional to the product of the the the size of the eye compartment the
number of infected individuals and number of susceptible individuals right you also have a reaction if you want to
call it an equation which tells you the rate of change of the compartment which are infected individuals so there
the incoming you know particles are individuals from s compartments are from the previous
term and then you have a rate of outflow and the rate is gamma in this case people recover at a rate of gamma
essentially and then you have the last equation which says that people recover at the rate of gamma and that's that's the last
equation here and that's a very very clean simple formulation of the problem but has been effective very very
effective for for you know for a long time the kinds of things you study from this are are epidemic quantities things which
is called an epidemic curve which tells you the time when you see the peak of an epidemic the
the time that the length of the epidemic uh the time when it takes off which means you see a sudden jump in
in the curve there are formally defined terms uh you can look it up in in the books but this
simple model actually has been immensely successful over the last hundred years and reason workhorse for epidemiologists
uh effectively was used by ross and others to control malaria when they're able to
effectively argue from these models how you might want to control malaria in the western world
it's very easy to extend add new compartments to it it's easy to to code if you want in in
today's matlab style codes and i think one of the reasons this became powerful and useful early on was that
you could have come up with analytical solutions in in early 1900's no computers and that's my conjecture of why a
different class of model that i'm going to talk about never really took hold and it's because people
wanted analytically closed form solutions there was no use of coming up with a representation theory which could not really be solved very
well you know you wanted to write the problem in a form that you could come up with solutions for uh and i think computers have changed that
this although the models have been very powerful they also have some weaknesses for instance they do not represent the
heterogeneity that that is inherent in social systems right and all of us are not identical so this
this heterogeneity that exists in our in urban set you know in in in social systems is is not
represented very well you can of course keep on breaking these things into smaller and smaller compartments but then
you sort of lose the appeal of the model in the first place the other aspect is representing of
human behavioral issues is quite hard in this system like this and finally
models like this it's not straightforward to come with what i would call implementable strategies for
interventions and hopefully i'll be able to give an example in the later part of the talk so what's
an alternative approach the alternative approach is now called networked epidemiology
and some of you here actually have written papers on this topic in in different context but the basic
hypothesis here is that a better understanding of the social contact structure and
individual behaviors is likely to give improved insight into how the
disease spread or the contagion spreads i'll use the word contagion and disease synonymously here and allow us to cover
better response strategies right and that's a hypothesis i hopefully i'll be able to convince you that
this this hopefully holds and the basic basic model is very very simple uh he's
a cartoon for it you have four notes um in this it's a graph
it's a network the disease starts at node one and you toss a coin
and the node one tries to infect node two at node three with probability p independently in this
particular case node 3 gets infected node 2 did not get infected
and let's say in this particular model node 1 recovers after one time unit in the next step three tries to infect
two and four in this case it's successfully infecting two but unsuccessfully infecting four
uh and it recovers and then two tries to infect four is not successful and you can write down
the probability of this event happening the probability is speed p one three which is the chance that
one sends a disease on the edge one three multiplied by one minus p one two which
is a chance that you know one was unsuccessful infecting two and one on and on so you can write the probability of this particular event
this particular configuration playing out right and this is the basic model you can now
add incubation times and so on so forth but this is actually an interesting
simple model that can capture a discrete time process an abstraction of the
problem of disease spreading now of course the problem which i'll come down later and tell you
is there are issues that come up with this model too you know it's not like this is a panacea for for the for the
problems i talked about from for od based models or mass action models a way to abstract this out even further
and i think it's a useful way to do it and that's how we have actually developed all our work is to view this as as a graphical
dynamical system so uh folks here are now hopefully uh you know well aware of two class of
graphical models that have been used heavily in computer science literature one is the graphical models for inference
which were popularized and have been very successful in over the last 10 years and then graphical models of games
what i'm proposing is that you can also have a graphical model for dynamical systems
and it's just an abstraction of the process that i described before the abstraction says that you instead of
having the simple coin toss and edge you have a local function on each edge which tells you how you would change
your state by looking at your own state and the neighbor state and the function could be either deterministic
or probabilistic and you can run the synchronously and you can think of this as computing a global function which is
obtained by composing these local functions together right this abstraction works out very well you can decide to have as i said a
deterministic local function or probabilistic one and that will change the dynamics
what is interesting then is that many many interesting epidemiological questions
can be cast as combinatorial problems on this graphical dynamical systems and that's
how you do the mapping hopefully you solve them well and then have something to say about the policy back
for instance the question of inference that and and we just talked to bruno here in the afternoon
can be clear you know classified in the setting where you say that you have observer time series
in this dynamical system and you're trying to infer the graph that might have led to this
particular time series you talk about forecasting in the falling manner you say that
disease starts from some place and then you want to understand how the disease would spread and what the state of the disease would
be after some time unit you can talk about interventions in this which is changing the properties of the vertices in terms of
functions or edges to try and control the pandemic or epidemic right so the problem is that from a
computational standpoint uh all this is good but
you're actually trying to reason about an object that is substantially larger than the than the representation itself
but in in particular in this particular setting the phase space which is the
representation of the possible dynamical outcomes is exponentially larger in a in when
your local functions are probabilistic turns out a good representation of is a markov chain and people have
interesting algorithms to analyze markov chain the problem with this situation is that the markov chain is
exponentially larger than the representation itself so that causes sort of computational
difficulties and i've tried to sort of articulate this here
the other problem in in this in this form of modeling is that well how would you even come up
with a representation of a social contact network if you want to study say flu in a city or ebola in in liberia
right so mathematically you have a network and you have this spread but you really don't
have any way of measuring this network in the real world in fact my i would argue that there's no way
that you can ever get an exact representation of this network by endless measurements this is just
impossibility right so you have to synthesize these networks the other problem that you face is that
you basically have actually grown the computational uh burden on yourself
a huge amount the other models are relatively simple these models become extremely hard to to
work with right so the next hypothesis then is that our advances in hpc and and data
science can actually help us solve these problems and and again what we've done is we have tried to
build a program called syndemics which tries to take this representation
theory of networks combines with hpc simulations uh with machine learning algorithms and a
way to synthesize these networks to try and and address important policy questions i'll give you a couple of examples of it
here along with it you got to build a middleware which you can allow
these models to be useful by the end users and that's where you come to the third
hypothesis which is that you know to make this program successful you
want to be able to push the models to end users in a rather seamless manner
we had done another project almost 10 years back on urban transport planning and it was actually very
successful in some ways but did not find traction in in the policy world and we learned the
hard way that we built very cool models at least we thought were cool models but really were made to be used by

that if you want to really take it to the policy makers or domain users you've got to really build systems
that they can understand and play with you know with no desire to convert them into computer
scientists and i think this is a message that we have learned the hard way and i think uh it's been successful work for us so we
have built out more than 15 apps there's around 12 here that i can see
but 15 different web apps which allow users to play with these backend models that are complicated but
in a way that they don't realize that these models are being used in this form right so specifications are clear and
i'll give you some examples of these models so i'll start going little faster i realize
that you know we should stop in about half an hour or so so i'll describe this program in five
steps uh you will construct a a synthetic population for a disease and then have a disease
model uh come up with simulations and then do analysis and i'll give you examples of
it i think the hardest part here to begin with is the construction of the network and i think it has got
multiple uses beyond epidemics the basic idea is we want to synthesize a social contact network to study
epidemics in a city right so for instance we have actually synthesized a social contact network to
study flu in in chicago what does this network
have to go back to our model each node represents an individual and what you want is that the
edges between nodes have to reflect the interaction between these nodes and the method that we have
used is is a first principle approach what it means that is that you use a combination of
data driven techniques use machine learning and statistical algorithms
combined with social and behavioral theories to synthesize it because there is no way i can get an exact representation of the
network in chicago this data you get is you you know
your process is very large it's a really interesting big data problem the papers outline why this is the case
just to give you a sense uh you know you can get in our case chicago network has over 11
million nodes and an average degree of 50 and you can compute the number of edges in this
network itself so the way we build this network out is uh is a series of steps um
using i would say a large number of different data sets uh from census to dun and brad street
to data about schools colleges health units to data about activity patterns that
people have on a day-to-day basis from transport planning offices these data sets are fused together to
build out a detailed social contact network and this actually started with our work back in in in transport
planning there are new data sets that are actually making this uh somewhat easier and i would say
interesting so barabashi and his group has used phone records
other groups have done it as well some folks have started to use twitter data foursquare was used before
to sort of map movement patterns which can be used in this the key in this network is
twofolds one is that this network is synthetic which means if i build a network for
chicago you cannot identify any person directly in
in my network at the same time it's statistically
very similar to the kind of network you might get in in place like chicago and how do we measure it
if you take a blog group in chicago and you look at any census variable for that block group that would
match the census that you would get for our population so it's a synthetic population uh there's one-to-one
correspondence between people in chicago and in our population no direct
mapping but statistically identical right and we've done a fair amount of work to try and convince
folks that this is a statistically accurate representation i also want to say that this is not
not a program that is going to end anytime soon as you get more and more data sets you can improve this
population but what is good about it is it really is designed at the get go to preserve privacy and
and kept keep the anonymity of of the individuals the second thing is these networks are
actually dynamic and relational which is very useful when we do this modeling that we talked about so
in this representation we have people on one side and locations on the other side people carry a range of attributes all
the attributes that they have measured in the census surveys age income
household size gender and on so on and so forth and the locations
have attributes such as you know what sort of folks work there how many people typically are there in that locations
uh other building codes that go with it and what do the edges represent they represent activities so person a might
visit a location b at a particular time this person might then go to location c
at between another time and on and on and now you have a basic structure from
which you can build out a context network you can say and you have to make it this inductive hypothesis saying that if
people for flu for instance if people are in the same location for a particular period of time
then i would put a interacting edge between them and this is a matter of convention right
if it's a different disease not aerosol bone disease the notion of an edge changes this is a
sort of a canonical representation from which you can derive the interaction structure based on the disease itself
they're very large this is the numbers that i have for chicago eight million odd people when we first made it now
almost ten million plus locations and edges that are changing in time and
have relational attributes on it we built a tool called siv it's actually available on the web
you can you know look at the population synthesize this way and disaggregate it
and you can sort of take a look at it will carry all the information that i've talked about
allows us to explain to uh you know policy makers this this aspect of synthetic
information visualization we then build disease progression models we use uh machine learning techniques to
look at data that one gets from limited experiments and the data people capture in small
households and try to assess disease parameters for within host transmission
we then do simulations of how the disease would spread uh through these networks and we have had
to use uh high performance computing platforms to do it it has been a challenge over the last
eight years as we have done this to scale up to uh to large populations and networks when we first did this back in 2002
we were studying portland and it was to take us 24 hours to to get even a single run
together in a meaningful way we can do this now much much faster and i've put some
numbers here because i find them interesting it's a piece of work that
my student and and colleagues have done about trying to scale this for u.s
the complete u.s 300 million nodes and approximately 15 billion interactions
on the largest open science hpc machine we have the blue waters at uiuc
and you can essentially do one run now or 200 days of epidemic simulation in about 30 seconds okay
and it you know of course computer scientists it's fun to do that but i think from policy standpoint this is
needed because if you want to do large experimental designs and counter factual you really need to make multiple runs so
first thing they are stochastic models so you need to get multiple replicates and then if you want to do intervention
analysis you want to actually try and study many many different cells in
the factorial design to understand this problem at this movie which i will try and play
if it plays where we did a study and it will show you a spatial spread of the disease

and then use that as a way to allocate vaccines so you find the node with highest vulnerability
or chance of getting sick and then assign these vaccines to these nodes we found out doing this empirical analysis that this
actually beats many many strategies that are you know were studied in the past
